name: Kepler-250
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-250 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-250 is a star with 0.7050000000000001 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.81 times its radius. It is located 2535.24 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-250 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-250 b

Kepler-250 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.05 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 4.15 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-250.

The mass of Kepler-250 b is 1.30 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-250 b is 1.13 that of Earth. At less than 1.5 Earth masses, Kepler-250 b is a regular terrestrial planet, much like the terrestrial planets we find in our solar system, namely Mercury, Venus, Earth and Mars.

Kepler-250 c

Kepler-250 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.07 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 7.16 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-250.

The mass of Kepler-250 c is 6.92 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-250 c is 2.28 that of Earth. At 6.92 Earth masses, Kepler-250 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-250 d

Kepler-250 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 17.65 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-250.

The mass of Kepler-250 d is 6.21 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-250 d is 2.18 that of Earth. At 6.21 Earth masses, Kepler-250 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-250, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
